page.title: 12CROMWELL COTTAGE, TILE HILL
page.content: The age of this cottage is difficult to date but 1653 is marked on the building. It was built in 2 parts, the first part being just one room with a dressed window. One theory is that it was a chapel of Eves, which makes sense as it was built in a religious area. The working cottage would have a hole in the wall, not a window. The second part would be timber frame and monastic stone. Nowadays the cottage has 3 rooms downstairs, the kitchen with an ancient bread oven, and 3 bedrooms and a bathroom upstairs. The garden is much smaller now and extremely overgrown. Legend says that Oliver Cromwell hid in a chimney of the cottage but there is no real evidence of this. However, Cromwell's soldiers, attacking Royalists defending the city, may have used the cottage for a night's rest.
